justification: Study 1 states that to examine implicit associations involving psychological distance, “participants completed a sorting paired features task (SPF; Bar-Anan et al., 2009).”
The same study reports that explicit associations for psychological distance were “measured … using visual analog scales (VAS).”
Study 5 notes that “In the SPF, participants categorized pairs of words … representing a high construal level … or a low construal level,” making the SPF the instrument for assessing construal level.
For explicit assessment, Study 5 explains that participants “indicated their answers using a visual analog scale,” linking VAS scores to construal level.
Study 9 says the action descriptions were “borrowed from Vallacher & Wegner’s (1989) Behavior Identification Form,” which participants used to choose high- vs. low-level identifications.
In Study 3, participants “indicate[d] [the pace of life] on a 175 mm slider anchored at ‘very slow’ … and ‘very fast’,” providing the quantitative measure.
Study 4 required participants to rate each action on “a 175 mm slider from ‘real’ … to ‘imaginary’,” operationalizing the hypotheticality construct.
Study 11 had listeners “drag and drop each audio into one of two boxes” labeled with contractive versus expansive scope, using this forced-choice format to gauge perceived regulatory scope.
